IMAGE-HIGH-RES APCATA 16616 S0926-860X(18)30172-8 10.1016/j.apcata.2018.04.010 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 The catalytic activities of the M3Co16Ox (A), Mn3Co16Ox and Mn3Co16Ox-free catalysts (B). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Stability of the Mn3Co16Ox (a) and Mn3Co16Ox-free (b) catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 HR-TEM images of the M3Co16Ox and Mn3Co16Ox-free catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 IR spectra of the M3Co16Ox catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XRD patterns of the M3Co16Ox catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 N2 adsorption and desorption curves of the M3Co16Ox catalysts (A) and the distribution of the BJH pore diameters (B). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 The H2-TPR profiles of M3Co16Ox and Co3O4 catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The CO-TPD profiles of M3Co16Ox and Co3O4 catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 XPS spectra of the M3Co16Ox Catalysts. Table 1 Different elements T100 (°C) 0.6 vol.% H2O Crystal size (nm) SBET (m2/g) Pore volume (cm3/g) Pore diameter (nm) Co 2p O 1s Element content Co3+/Co2+ vO (%) OS (%) OL (%) C(%) O(%) Cr3Co16Ox 120 15.1 140.9 0.56 7.3 1.13 9.1 31.4 59.4 10.89 55.09 Ti3Co16Ox 85 12.3 119.6 0.61 8.4 1.26 12.3 27.6 60.1 10.57 54.87 Zr3Co16Ox 75 11.3 119.2 0.53 7.0 1.39 14.0 25.2 60.7 10.29 58.87 Fe3Co16Ox 65 11.1 113.0 0.51 5.8 1.47 16.7 21.6 61.7 13.43 46.30 Mn3Co16Ox 55 10.5 120.8 0.50 4.8 1.56 17.5 20.3 62.2 13.78 52.47 A highly moisture-resistant binary M3Co16Ox composite oxide catalysts wrapped by polymer nanofilm for effective low temperature CO oxidation Yan Zhou Jun Yu ⁎ Dongsen Mao Haifang Mao Xiaoming Guo Chao Sun Houjin Huang ⁎ Research Institute of Applied Catalysis, School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Institute of Technology, Shanghai 201418, PR China Research Institute of Applied Catalysis School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering Shanghai Institute of Technology Shanghai 201418 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A series of M3Co16Ox (M = Cr, Ti, Zr, Fe, Mn) oxide catalysts wrapped by polymer nanofilm were developed by the solid-phase method, and the catalytic activities were investigated for low temperature oxidation of carbon monoxide under moisture-rich condition. The catalysts were characterized by HR-TEM, FT-IR, XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, H2-TPR, CO-TPD and XPS techniques. The results reveal that the M3Co16Ox composite oxides are high-dispersive mesoporous materials coated by polymer nanofilm with an average thickness in the scope of 4–7 nm. The percentages of surface oxygen vacancy and lattice oxygen on the catalysts decrease in the following order: Mn3Co16Ox > Fe3Co16Ox > Zr3Co16Ox > Ti3Co16Ox > Cr3Co16Ox, which is consistent with their catalytic performances. Among all the prepared catalysts, the polymer nanofilm wrapped Mn3Co16Ox nanoparticles possess the highest Co3+/Co2+ ratio (1.56), the highest percentage of surface oxygen vacancy (17.5%) and lattice oxygen (62.2%), resulting in the best catalytic activity, such as, 100% conversion at 55 °C under moisture-rich condition (∼0.6 vol.%). Moreover, the Mn3Co16Ox catalyst also exhibits long-term catalytic stability (>one month) even at a very high water vapor level (3.1 vol.%) and considerably low temperature (85 °C). Keywords M3Co16Ox Catalyst Polymer nanofilm wrapped nanoparticles Moisture-resistant Low temperature CO oxidation 1 Introduction CO, which is derived from incomplete combustion of carbon compounds, is a pernicious ambient pollutant and exceedingly perilous for humans as well as the environment [1–4]. Low temperature catalytic carbon monoxide oxidation has played a significant role in CO elimination, such as air purification, automobile emission control, indoor gas detection, and removing trace quantities of CO in enclosed atmospheres [3–5]. Currently, increasing attention has been committed to hunting for active and stable substitute catalysts with various transition metal oxides or composite oxides which are of low cost and that present high activity [6–31]. Among the oxides of said metals, spinel cobalt oxide catalyst has demonstrated high conversion levels for CO oxidation even at room temperature [15–18]. Unfortunately, Co3O4 is deactivated quickly in the presence of trace amounts of water vapour at ambient atmosphere, which restricts its application in industry [19–23]. The covering of H2O on the Co3+ active sites can hinder the adsorption of CO and oxygen, resulting in the deactivation of the catalyst. Therefore, the development of active and water-resistant Co-based catalysts for low temperature CO oxidation is still awaited, and remains a vital challenge [16,24]. The previous study by Xie and co-workers has reported that Co3O4 nanorods actively and quite stably catalyzed CO oxidation with T100 (the reaction temperature of 100% conversion) of −77 °C under normal feed gas including water vapour at a level of 3–10 ppm, however, the catalytic activity maintained only in the initial 6 h, and decreased sharply (∼20% loss) after 12 h [16]. Although numerous studies have pointed out that the addition of metal dopants could enhance the stability of Co-based catalysts to some extent, the reaction temperature still over 100 °C in the presence of moisture [22–28,32,33]. Up to now no studies have succeeded in proving a satisfactory metal-doped Co-based catalyst with lasting catalytic activity and stability for low temperature CO oxidation in humid circumstance. Within this context, in order to block the H2O molecules and keep the high reactivity of Co-based catalysts in humid circumstance, the notion of covering a protective layer with hydrophobicity on the catalysts was devised. For instance, the polydimethylsiloxane coated Co3O4 can help to prevent deactivation in the presence of water, but this polymer layer also seriously blocks the active sites reaching the reactants [32]. In our previous work, we innovatively designed a nanofilm-coated Fe3Co16Ox catalyst, which exhibited the outstanding activity and stability even at the temperature as low as 90 °C with a high moisture level (3.1 vol.%), but the temperature of complete catalytic oxidation CO was still relatively high [33]. Therefore, in this work, we tried to synthesize a series of nanofilm-coated M3Co16Ox composite oxides, and further seek a better Co-based catalyst for the lower temperature CO conversion at a high moisture level. The structure and surface properties of the nanofilm-coated M3Co16Ox materials were undertaken by extensive characterization, to illuminate a better understanding of the structure-activity relationships of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Nanofilm-coated M3Co16Ox catalyst synthesis A series of binary M3Co16Ox oxide catalysts were prepared by the solid-phase method as reported in our previous work [33]. In a typical synthesis, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (≥99.0%), Cr(NO3)3·9H2O (≥99.0%), oxalic acid (OA, ≥99.0%) and ethlyeneglycol (EG, ≥99.0%) at calculated ratios were measured and ground in an agate mortar for 30 min. Then the mixed solution was transferred from the agate mortar into a glass cup. After being ultrasonicated for 1 h, the sample was dried at 110 °C overnight and then calcined at 230 °C for 4 h. The catalyst was denoted as Cr3Co16Ox. Other M3Co16Ox (M = Ti, Zr, Fe, Mn) oxide catalysts (Co/M = 16:3, EG/OA = 1:1, mol) were prepared through the same procedure. 2.2 Mn3Co16Ox-free catalyst synthesis The Mn3Co16Ox catalyst without coating polymer was prepared as follows. The Mn3Co16Ox catalyst (2 g) was dissolved in dichloromethane (10 mL) in a 20 mL vial, followed by the addition of trifluoroacetic acid (2 mL). After stirring at room temperature for 36 h, the solvent was removed by vacuum. The sample was then dissolved in 10 mL of THF and precipitated in the mixed solution of hexane and ethlyeneglycol four times. After drying the sample in vacuum at 40 °C, it was calcined at 230 °C for 4 h. The catalyst was denoted as Mn3Co16Ox-free. 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic performance of M3Co16Ox and Mn3Co16Ox-free catalysts for CO oxidation was examined in a continuous flow quartz tubular fixed-bed reactor under ambient pressure. As-prepared catalyst (200 mg) and silica sand were loaded into the reactor and pretreated at 200 °C for 30 min under N2. The feed gas containing 0.15% CO, 18.9% O2, and 80.95% N2 was passed through the catalyst with a space velocity (WHSV) of 15,000 mL/(gcat∙h). After the steady operation for 10 min at any given temperature, the CO and CO2 concentrations in the outlet gas stream were monitored directly by an online gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with the nickel methanation furnace and hydrogen flame ionization detector (FID). Moisture rich condition was obtained by passing the feed gas through a water bubbler at 0 °C (∼0.6 vol.% water vapor), and the concentration of water vapor was varied by adjusting the temperature of the water bubbler. The CO conversion (X(CO)) was calculated as follows: X(CO) = 1 - C(CO)out/C(CO)in × 100%, where C(CO)in and C(CO)out denote the concentrations of CO in the inlet and outlet, respectively. 2.4 Materials characterization The morphology and detailed microstructure of the M3Co16Ox and Mn3Co16Ox-free catalysts were analyzed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) on Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN (FEI Corporation) electron microscope operating at 200 kV. The FT-IR spectra were measured in a range of 400–4000 cm−1 at room temperature by Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer. The crystalline structures of the M3Co16Ox catalysts were investigated via X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns using PANalytical X'Pert Pro MRD X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154056 nm), and operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. The mean crystalline sizes of Co3O4 in the M3Co16Ox catalysts were estimated from the following Scherrer equation: D = κλ/βcosθ, where β is the broadening at half the maximum intensity (rad), θ is the diffraction angle, and κ is a dimensionless number (κ = 0.89). The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the M3Co16Ox catalysts were recorded on a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 HD88 adsorption apparatus at −196 °C, and the surface areas were calculated by the Brumauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The reduction property of the M3Co16Ox catalysts was analyzed using hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 50 mg (40–60 mesh) sample was preheated at 200 °C for 0.5 h and cooled to 50 °C under N2 (50 mL/min) flow. The prepared catalyst was heated up to 700 °C at 10 °C/min in the flow of 10% H2/N2 (50 mL/min). Temperature-programmed desorption of CO (CO-TPD) was performed in a continuous flow apparatus provided with quadruple mass spectrometer (QMS, Balzers OmniStar 200). 100 mg (40–60 mesh) of sample was pretreated at 200 °C for 0.5 h in pure He flow (30 mL/min), and cooled to room temperature, then pure flowing CO (30 mL/min) was introduced into the catalyst bed for 1 h. After that, the gas was swept again with He. Subsequently, the prepared catalyst was heated up to 680 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, and the mass signals of CO (m/z = 28), CO2 (m/z = 44) were detected. The chemical binding states of the samples were investigated through the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi with a monochromatized aluminum Kα radiation source. Notably, all binding energies (BE) were determined with reference to the C1s line (284.6 eV) emanating from adventitious carbon. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity of M3Co16Ox and Mn3Co16Ox-free catalysts for CO oxidation The catalytic performances of the M3Co16Ox and Mn3Co16Ox-free Catalysts for CO oxidation with 0.6 vol.% moisture condition are shown in Fig. 1 . As shown in Fig. 1(A), the T100 over Cr3Co16Ox was 120 °C. Compared with the Cr3Co16Ox catalyst, the modification of Ti and Zr significantly enhanced the catalytic activity with CO total conversion at 85 °C and 75 °C, respectively. It is obvious that the activity of Fe3Co16Ox catalyst was further higher than those of Zr3Co16Ox and Ti3Co16Ox, for which the T100 appeared at 65 °C. Interestingly, the Mn3Co16Ox sample demonstrated the highest catalytic activity, successfully converting 100% of CO at temperature around 55 °C. For all the prepared M3Co16Ox samples, the activities decreased in the following sequence: Mn3Co16Ox > Fe3Co16Ox > Zr3Co16Ox > Ti3Co16Ox > Cr3Co16Ox. For a comparison, the catalytic activity of the Mn3Co16Ox samples before and after removing of the coating nano-films were also compared in Fig. 1(B). Compared to the catalyst of Mn3Co16Ox, the T100 value (60 °C) of the Mn3Co16Ox-free catalyst was slightly increased. It is indicated that the presence of polymer films in the M3Co16Ox catalysts cannot effect the intrinsic catalytic properties. 3.2 Catalytic stability Moisture content acts as a vital deteriorating factor for CO oxidation over the Co-based catalysts. Due to the best catalytic activity of the Mn3Co16Ox catalyst, it was selected for reaction stability test operating at 85 °C, 80 °C and 70 °C under the high moisture content (∼3.1 vol.%), and the test results are shown in Fig. 2 (a). The Mn3Co16Ox catalyst demonstrated excellent catalytic stability and water resistance under moisture-rich condition. At 80 °C, the 90% CO conversion originally was obtained, then it deteriorated gradually, but maintained >80% CO conversion after 248 h, and finally stabilized at 75% conversion after 300 h. When the reaction temperature declined to 70 °C, the CO conversion dropped from 71% to 57% after 140 h, and 57% conversion could be kept before the reaction stopped at 184 h. Moreover, no obvious deactivation of the Mn3Co16Ox catalyst could be observed at 85 °C for over one month (100% conversion, stopped observation at 720 h). In addition, the catalytic stability of Mn3Co16Ox-free operated at 80 °C with 3.1 vol.% moisture condition was examined, and the result is demonstrated in Fig. 2(b). The 80% CO conversion of the Mn3Co16Ox-free catalyst was obtained originally, then it decreased quickly as the function of time. The result proves that the coating polymer has positive effects on the catalytic activity and water resistance, which can isolate water molecules from the coated metal oxides to inhibit water molecules adsorbing on the active sites of catalyst, and further restraining the formation of carbonates on the metal oxide catalyst. According to literatures [16,19,22,24–28,32], under a moisture-rich condition, the majority of Co-based catalysts demanded a temperature of above 100 °C for complete catalytic CO oxidation. Song et al. [19] synthesized the mesoporous Co3O4 catalyst, and found that under 3 vol.% H2O condition, the CO conversion was decreased from 100% to 50% at 100 °C after 24 h and showed no obvious recovery after operating under a higher temperature. Our previously prepared polymer-nanofilm coated Fe3Co16Ox catalyst [33], which could achieve 100% CO conversion at 90 °C under moisture-rich condition (∼3 vol.% H2O), but the CO conversion was decreased from 60% to 45% at the low temperature of 70 °C after 145 h. Compared with these results, the Mn3Co16Ox catalyst prepared in this work significantly improves the water resistance and stability. 3.3 Catalyst characterization 3.3.1 HR-TEM As shown in HR-TEM images (Fig. 3 ), the morphologies of M3Co16Ox and Mn3Co16Ox-free particles are irregular spheres or ovals. Characteristic spinel Co3O4(111) crystal structures can be detected in all the catalysts, while no crystal grains of the other transition metal elements can be observed, which suggests that the other transition metal elements may be well-dispersed or doped into the Co3O4 crystal lattices. The average Co3O4 particles sizes of all the catalysts are smaller than 15 nm, while the largest average particle size of the Cr3Co16Ox catalyst is 14.7 nm. Remarkably, all of M3Co16Ox nanoparticles are covered by the polymer coating layer with mean thickness in the range of 4–7 nm, which is slightly thicker than that of Fe3Co16Ox catalyst calcined at 250 °C [33], suggesting that the lower calcination temperature may be beneficial to the formation of the macromolecule nanofilm layer. Moreover, there is no polymer nanofilm coated on the surface of Mn3Co16Ox-free catalyst, suggesting that the coating polymer was removed successfully. 3.3.2 FT-IR The IR spectra of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 4 . All the catalysts showed a wide and strong absorption peaks at 3200–3670 cm−1, which are assigned to the stretching vibration of OH groups. The absorption peaks near 1630 cm−1 are attributed to the deformation vibration of H2O [34,35]. The peaks located at 1388 cm−1 are associated with the deformation vibration of -CH2 or -CH3 groups [35,36]. The peaks at 1320 cm−1 may originate from the absorption of bidentate carbonate species [37,38], and two sharp peaks at around 661 and 564 cm−1 can be assigned to the Co3+ O and Co2+ O stretching, respectively [25,35]. The M3Co16Ox catalysts showed different intensities of the absorption peaks near 3432, 1630, 1388, 1320, 661 and 564 cm−1. The absorption peaks at 1388 cm−1 could be found on all the samples, indicating the presence of the coating polymer ((CH2CH2 OCOCOO)n) on the catalysts surface, and it is consistent with the results of HR-TEM. The carbonate species can be observed in the M3Co16Ox (M = Cr, Ti, Zr) catalysts, while they are hardly visible over the Fe3Co16Ox and Mn3Co16Ox catalysts, probably owing to slightly different decomposition degrees caused by different M-Co interactions. 3.3.3 XRD The crystalline structures of the resulting M3Co16Ox composites are obtained from the XRD patterns (Fig. 5 ). As indicated, all characteristic diffraction peaks are matched with the spinel-structure cobalt phase (JCPDS 43-1003) reference pattern. Since no diffraction peaks of other elements can be observed, other elements might be highly dispersed in the Co3O4, or form M3Co16Ox solid solutions. These results are in consistent with the results of HR-TEM. Moreover, from the Cr3Co16Ox to Mn3Co16Ox catalyst, the intensity of Co3O4 diffraction peaks gradually increase, illustrating that relatively better crystallines have been obtained in the Mn3Co16Ox and Fe3Co16Ox catalysts. The average crystallite sizes of all catalysts calculated by the Scherrer equation are shown in Table 1 . As seen, the average Co3O4 particle sizes in the M3Co16Ox (M = Ti, Zr, Fe) are almost the same (11–12 nm). The Cr3Co16Ox catalyst has the largest Co3O4 particle size (15.1 nm), suggesting that the doping of Cr is detrimental to the dispersion of Co3O4. In contrast, the smallest Co3O4 particle size (10.5 nm) is obtained in the Mn3Co16Ox catalyst, meaning that the presence of Mn can promote the dispersion of Co3O4. Combined with the catalytic performance, it is suggested that the higher dispersion of Co3O4 is beneficial to the improvement of catalytic activity. 3.3.4 N2 adsorption-desorption The Fig. 6 reveals the N2 adsorption isothermal curves and the BJH desorption pore size distributions of the M3Co16Ox catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6A, the M3Co16Ox catalysts appear to be a typical IV-type of isothermal curve, meaning that the samples are characterized by regular mesoporous structure. At the same time, similar but different distribution profiles of the pore diameters (5–15 nm) can be seen in the Fig. 6B. The specific surface areas, pore volumes and pore diameters of all the catalysts are also listed in Table 1. In accordance with Table 1, the average pore diameters can be arranged in the order of the Mn3Co16Ox (4.8 nm) < Fe3Co16Ox (5.8 nm) < Zr3Co16Ox (7.0 nm) < Cr3Co16Ox (7.3 nm) < Ti3Co16Ox (8.4 nm). The specific surface areas of the M3Co16Ox (M = Ti, Zr, Fe, Mn) catalysts are about 110-120 m2/g, while that of the Cr3Co16Ox catalyst is 140.9 m2/g. In combination with the activity data, it is inferred that no intrinsic interconnection can be found between the specific surface area and the catalytic activity. 3.3.5 H2-TPR Fig. 7 shows the TPR profiles for all the samples. The pure Co3O4 catalyst has two reduction peaks, which are corresponding to the two-step reduction of Co3O4 (Co3O4→CoO→Co) in which the low-temperature reduction peak α can be attributed to the reduction of Co3O4→CoO [19,39,40]. After doping M into Co3O4, the peak (α) shifts to lower temperature while the reduction peak area increases generally. Compared with all the other samples tested in this work, the Mn3Co16Ox catalyst shows the lowest reduction temperature and the highest reduction peak (α) area. It is proposed that there are different interactions between Co and M. The decrease in reduction temperatures accompanied by the increase in reduction areas of the peak (α) may be attributed to the improving dispersion of Co3O4 caused by the doping of M. Furthermore, the reducibility of the catalysts follows the order: Mn3Co16Ox > Fe3Co16Ox > Zr3Co16Ox > Ti3Co16Ox > Cr3Co16Ox > Co3O4, which is consistent with the result of XRD. These results are also in accordance with their catalytic activities, that is, the easier the reduction the higher the catalytic activity [19]. 3.3.6 CO-TPD Fig. 8 shows the curves of CO2 desorption after CO absorption in absence of O2 over the catalysts. As shown in the pattern of pure Co3O4, there is a strong CO2 desorption peak (α) in the range of 50–300 °C. According to relevant literatures, the peak (α) should be formed by the reaction between the absorbed CO and surface oxygen species [41,42]. After doping with M, the peak areas have been changed substantially. The peak areas of the CO2 desorption follow the order: Mn3Co16Ox > Fe3Co16Ox > Zr3Co16Ox > Ti3Co16Ox > Cr3Co16Ox > Co3O4, which is in line with their catalytic activities. The Mn3Co16Ox catalyst exhibits the maximum peak area. The highest ability of CO adsorption was obtained on its catalyst surface, which should be one of the crucial factors for its optimal CO catalytic activity. 3.3.7 XPS Fig. 9 presents the XPS spectra of the M3Co16Ox catalysts to investigate the composition of surface elements and chemical valence states. In Fig. 9A the peaks ∼780 and ∼795 eV are corresponding to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively, indicating the existence of Co3O4 in the catalysts [43,44]. The spectrum of the Co 2p could be further divided into Co2+ (782 and 796 eV), Co3+ (780 and 795 eV) and Co2+ satellite peaks (789 and 804 eV), respectively [34,37,44]. The ratio of surface Co3+/Co2+ of the M3Co16Ox catalysts can be calculated by the peak areas, and the distribution of the catalyst surface elements and their corresponding chemical states are given in Table 1. Accordingly, the surface Co3+/Co2+ atomic ratio increases gradually from the Cr3Co16Ox catalyst to the Mn3Co16Ox catalyst. The highest Co3+/Co2+ ratio can be obtained from the Mn3Co16Ox sample (∼1.56), which is in consistent with its highest catalytic activity. Combined with the activity data and the result of CO-TPD, the CO molecules are speculated to be mainly absorbed on the Co3+ sites, thus the high Co3+/Co2+ atomic ratio can promote the catalytic activity [16,45]. As shown in Fig. 9B, the O 1s spectrograms could be split into three oxygen species. The peak near 529.9 eV can be assigned to the lattice oxygens (OL, such as CoO or MO), while the peaks around 531 eV and 532 eV can be attributed to the surface oxygen species (OS, such as OH−, O2‒ or O−) and oxygen vacancies (vO) respectively [19,46,47]. The CO oxidation reaction over the Co-based catalysts follows the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. Namely, CO adsorbed on Co3+ extracts adjacent lattice oxygen to form Co2+, CO2 and oxygen vacancies, and then O2 adsorbs in the oxygen vacancy and oxidizes Co2+ to Co3+ [33,34,41]. The percentages of OL, OS and vO are given in Table 1. The percentage of surface oxygen vacancy and surface lattice oxygen increased gradually from the Cr3Co16Ox catalyst to Mn3Co16Ox catalyst, and the highest amounts of oxygen vacancies (17.5%) as well as lattice oxygen (62.2%) were obtained on the surface of Mn3Co16Ox catalyst. The amount of surface oxygen vacancy is conformed with the catalytic activity of the catalysts. In other words, adding an appropriate amount of Mn to Co3O4 can facilitate the generation of the highest oxygen vacancy and enhance the mobility of surface lattice oxygen, resulting in the excellent catalytic performance of Mn3Co16Ox catalyst. The surface content of C and O are also given in Table 1. It is observed that all samples have similar surface C content, which suggested the existence of the polymer layer. Moreover, the content of oxygen is much higher than the theoretical oxygen content of the polymer layer. It is inferred that the XPS can detect not only the oxygen of polymer layer, but also the oxygen of metal oxides. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a series of M3Co16Ox catalysts were synthesized by a facile method and wrapped by the polymer nanofilm, and the catalytic activities were investigated for effective and long-term stable low temperature oxidation of carbon monoxide under moisture-rich condition. The descending catalytic performance of the catalysts followed the order: Mn3Co16Ox > Fe3Co16Ox > Zr3Co16Ox > Ti3Co16Ox > Cr3Co16Ox. The results manifested that the Mn3Co16Ox catalyst showed the best catalytic activity for CO oxidation, and ∼100% CO conversion could be obtained at 55 °C under misture-rich condition (∼0.6 vol.% H2O). Meanwhile, the catalyst of Mn3Co16Ox also exhibited the excellent H2O tolerance and remarkable long-term catalytic stability (>one month) due to the protection of the coated polymer nanofilm. The results of structural characterization suggested that the M3Co16Ox catalysts are highly dispersed mesoporous nanoparticles wrapped by polymer nanofilm with mean thickness in the range of of 4–7 nm. The higher dispersion of Co3O4, the higher ability of CO adsorption, the higher Co3+/Co2+ ratio as well as surface lattice oxygen and oxygen vacancy were observed from the Cr3Co16Ox catalyst to Mn3Co16Ox catalyst. Furthermore, the synergistic interaction between Co and Mn can maximally promote the dispersion of Co3O4, and facilitate the generation of the active sites (Co3+), resulting in the highest ability of CO adsorption. Moreover, the doping of Mn can facilitate the generation of the highest oxygen vacancy (17.5%) and enhance the mobility of surface lattice oxygen, which are responsible for the excellent catalytic performance of Mn3Co16Ox catalyst. coredata.dc:description: A series of M3Co16Ox (M = Cr, Ti, Zr, Fe, Mn) oxide catalysts wrapped by polymer nanofilm were developed by the solid-phase method, and the catalytic activities were investigated for low temperature oxidation of carbon monoxide under moisture-rich condition. The catalysts were characterized by HR-TEM, FT-IR, XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, H2-TPR, CO-TPD and XPS techniques. The results reveal that the M3Co16Ox composite oxides are high-dispersive mesoporous materials coated by polymer nanofilm with an average thickness in the scope of 4–7 nm. The percentages of surface oxygen vacancy and lattice oxygen on the catalysts decrease in the following order: Mn3Co16Ox > Fe3Co16Ox > Zr3Co16Ox > Ti3Co16Ox > Cr3Co16Ox, which is consistent with their catalytic performances. Among all the prepared catalysts, the polymer nanofilm wrapped Mn3Co16Ox nanoparticles possess the highest Co3+/Co2+ ratio (1.56), the highest percentage of surface oxygen vacancy (17.5%) and lattice oxygen (62.2%), resulting in the best catalytic activity, such as, 100% conversion at 55 °C under moisture-rich condition (∼0.6 vol.%). Moreover, the Mn3Co16Ox catalyst also exhibits long-term catalytic stability (>one month) even at a very high water vapor level (3.1 vol.%) and considerably low temperature (85 °C).
coredata.dc:title: A highly moisture-resistant binary M3Co16Ox composite oxide catalysts wrapped by polymer nanofilm for effective low temperature CO oxidation
